Award.AwardTitle: US-German Collaboration: The effects of chloride dynamics in cerebellar computation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although inhibitory synapses are only a small fraction of all the connections present in the nervous system, without them brains cannot function and animals die. A large majority of inhibitory synapses are mediated by chloride currents that flow through the cell membrane when the synapses are activated. The objective of this project is to quantify the effects of changes in chloride concentration inside cells on the strength of inhibitory synapses. For this purpose a genetically encoded molecule, designed at the University of Heidelberg in Germany, will be expressed in Purkinje cells in the cerebellum at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA). These cells are involved in motor control and learning. These changes will be measured with a state-of-the art microscope at UTSA, and the results will be shared with collaborators at Goethe University in Frankfurt, Germany. In collaboration, the UTSA and German teams will develop computer models that will be used to predict the behavior of inhibitory synapses on Purkinje cells during complex sensory and motor tasks. These models will be used to determine how the cerebellar cortex processes motor and sensory information under conditions in which chloride changes due to the complex structure of neurons or due to changes in the metabolism of cells. The results obtained from this project will determine how changes in chloride concentration contribute to the normal functioning of the brain. Furthermore, the education of students at UTSA, a minority serving institution, will be enhanced and enriched by offering opportunities to do collaborative research with German Universities.


A companion project is being funded by the German Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to understand how the principal cells of the cerebellar cortex, the Purkinje cells, integrate chemical information in ther complex dendritic trees. The cerebellum is believed to be an organ that integrates and predicts sensory information for a wide range of behaviors, from motor control to higher congitive tasks. All these compuations are ultimately reported by Purkinje cells. In particular, the team was interested in studying how chloride ions accumulated inside Purkinje cell dendrites due to the activation of inhibitory synapses. The dynamics of chloride accumulations could diminish the relative strenght of these synapses and change the balance of synaptic integration in Purkinje cells.

Intellectual merit

The team collaborated to express a molecule that can measure the concentraiton of chloride inside Purkinje cells. The hypothesis was that the concentration depended on the actvitiy of inhibitory synapses. However, the team found that the contration of chloride dependend on the cellular comportment. It was low at the soma and high at the dendrites. To address this issue, the team did a modeling study to quantify the contribution of the complex dendritic structure on the accumulation of chloride, suggesting that the high density of dendritic spines slow down chloride diffusion, thus contributing to its accumulation. Further work concentrated in modeling the effects of chloride in the activity of the Purkinje cell and to measure how the activity of the neuron changes after induction of synaptic plasticity . Overall, the work shows that the complex dendritic tree contributes to the accumulation of intracellular singals that can modify the coding capabilities of the Purkinje cell.

Broader impacts

The project resulted in the training of 1 postdoc and 3 PhD students. The postdoc transitioned to the private sector in biomedical applicaitons. Two of the students have graduated and have started postdoctoral training. One graduate student is scheduled to graduate this year.
